text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
I love where I come from.

To me, there is
absolutely nothing better

than the smell of fresh
cut hay, dirt roads,
or the purr of a diesel engine.

But I also love
Harvard Business School

because of the diversity,
and the people,
and the intellectual curiosity.

It is literally the
most inspirational place
that I have ever been.

Now each of these two places
are very special and unique
in their own way.

But the real magic happens
when you take these two worlds
and combine them.

And my life's purpose
is to create more magic.

Last year I had the
distinct opportunity

to lead an HBS trek
to West Virginia,

and we just so happened to
end up near my hometown.

On our last day,
our car broke down

and we weren't sure if we would
get to the airport in time.

But fortunately for us, my
Dad who's a truck driver

had the day off, and so he was
able to pick us up in his truck
and drive us to Pittsburgh.

Now I didn't think that my
Dad who was a truck driver

and grew up on a dairy farm,
and didn't finish college

would have anything in common
with a group of Ivy League
students from the city.

But nothing could have been
farther from the truth.

On the car ride
up to Pittsburgh,
the conversation was electric.

They talked about everything
from dairy farms to steel

mills, and consulting projects,
and everything in between.

And when we got home
that night, both my Dad

and my friends from
HBS privately told me

how happy and grateful they were
to have had that time to share
with one another.

Now my goal in life
is to get more of HBS

into the cab of my
Dad's truck, so we
can continue that conversation.

Sure, my primary goal is to be
a champion for rural America,

but there is so much
that each of these groups
can learn from one another.

And I personally believe that
if we can unlock the latent

potential that lies in
our common experience

and our shared values,
we can create more magic
in this world.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
